words.ENTRY: <H>T-shirt</H><audio>T-shirt.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a shirt with short sleeves, a round opening for your head to go through and no buttons</D>

<H>talk</H><audio>talk.mp3</audio><PS>verb </PS><CF>talk (to/with somebody)</CF>; <CF>talk (about somebody/something)</CF> <D>to say things; to speak:</D> <X>I could hear them talking downstairs.</X><dot><X>Their little boy is just learning to talk.</X><dot><X>Can I talk to you for a minute?</X><dot><X>We need to talk about the plans for the weekend.</X>

<H>tall</H><audio>tall.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>(used about people or things) of more than average height; not short:</D> <X>a tall young man</X><dot><X>a tall tree/tower</X><dot><X>Nick is taller than his brother.</X><dot><X>He is six feet three inches tall.</X>

taste1verb(not in the -ing forms) 1.to be aware of or recognize the flavor of food or drink: Can you taste the garlic in this soup?2.taste (like something) to have a particular flavor: Some people say that frog legs taste like chicken.to taste sour/sweet/
delicioustaste1noun1.uncountablethe ability to recognize the flavor of food or drink: Taste is one of the five senses.2.singularthe flavor of food or drink: I don't like the taste of this coffee.
taxi (plural taxis) nouncountablea car with a driver, whose job is to take you somewhere in exchange for money: Do you want to drive there or take a taxi?

teachverb(past, past participle taught) to give somebody lessons or instructions so that he/she knows how to do something: Colin is teaching us how to use the computer.My mother taught me to play the piano.He teaches English to international students.

<H>teacher</H><audio>teacher.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person whose job is to teach, especially in a school:</D> <X>Mrs. Wilson was my science teacher in eighth grade.</X><dot><X>a piano teacher</X>

tellverb(past, past participle told) tell somebody (something); tell something (to somebody) to give information to somebody by speaking or writing: She told me her address, but I forgot it.Tell us about your vacation.Tell me what you did yesterday.to tell the truth/a lieto tell a storyExcuse me, can you tell me where the post office is?
<H>temple</H><audio>temple.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a building where people pray and worship in some religions:</D> <X>a Buddhist temple</X>

tennisnoununcountablea game for two or four players who hit a ball to each other over nets with rackets: Let's play tennis.
a tennis match

tensenouncountable, uncountable (grammar) a form of a verb that shows whether something happens in the past, present,
or future

<H>terrible</H><audio>terrible.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>very bad; of low quality:</D> <X>The hotel was terrible.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>very bad or serious:</D> <X>a terrible accident</X><dot><X>That was a terrible thing to do!</X><NR>3.</NR><D>sick or very upset:</D> <X>I feel terrible. I think I'm going to throw up!</X><dot><X>You look terrible. Are you all right?</X><dot><X>He felt terrible when he realized what he had done.</X>

<H>text message</H><audio>text_message.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a written message that you send using a cellular phone:</D> <X>Send a text message to this number to vote.</X> <H>text-message</H><audio>text_message.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to write and send text messages</D>

thanconjunction; preposition1.(used when you are comparing two things): He's taller than you.New York is more expensive than most cities.You speak French a lot better than she does.2.(used with more and less before numbers, expressions of time, distance, etc.): He earns more than $50,000 a year.

<H>thank</H><audio>thank.mp3</audio><PS>verb </PS><CF>thank somebody (for something/for doing something)</CF> <D>to tell somebody that you are grateful: <X>I'm writing to thank you for the present you sent me.</X><dot><X>I'll go and thank him for offering to help.</X><dot><X>"Have a piece of cake." "Thank you. It looks delicious."</X>
thanksinterjection(informal) thank you: Thanks a lot!"Would you like another cup of coffee?" "No, thanks."

that1determiner; pronoun(plural those) (used for describing a person or thing, especially when it is not near the person speaking): I like that house over there.What's that on the road?"Can you hand me the book?" "This one?" "No, that one over there."that2 (strong form)conjunction(used after certain verbs, nouns and adjectives to introduce a new part of the sentence): She told me that she was leaving.I hope that you feel better soon.I'm sure that he will come.

<H>the</H><audio>the.mp3</audio><PS>definite article</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>(used for talking about a person or thing that is already known or that has already been mentioned):</D> <X>I took the kids to the dentist.</X><dot><X>The Johnsons are on vacation.</X><dot><X>We met the man who bought your house.</X><dot><X>The milk is in the refrigerator.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used when there is only one or only one group):</D> <X>The sun is very strong today.</X><dot><X>Who won the team championship?</X><NR>3.</NR><D>(with musical instruments):</D> <X>Do you play the piano?</X>

<H>theater</H><audio>theater.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a building where you go to see plays, etc.:</D> <X>I'm going to the theater.</X> (= to see a play) <NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a building where you go to see movies; movie theater</D>
<H>their</H><audio>their.mp3</audio><PS>determiner</PS><D>belonging to them:</D> <X>What color is their car?</X><dot><X>The students picked up their books and walked to the door.</X>
<H>theirs</H><audio>theirs.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>of or belonging to them:</D> <X>Our house isn't as big as theirs.</X>

<H>them</H><audio>them.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS>(the object of a verb or preposition) <D>the people, animals or things mentioned earlier or being observed now:</D> <X>I'll call them now.</X><dot><X>"I have the keys here." "Oh, good. Give them to me."</X><dot><X>We have students from several countries, but most of them are Mexican.</X><dot><X>"Did you mail those letters?" "Oh, no! I forgot about them."</X>

<H>then</H><audio>then.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>next; after that:</D> <X>We're going hiking in the mountains for a week and then to the beach.</X><dot><X>There was silence for a minute. Then he replied.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(at) that time:</D> <X>In 1996? I was in college then.</X><dot><X>I'll be on vacation then.</X><dot><X>I'm going tomorrow. Can you wait until then?</X>

there1adverbin, at, or to that place: Put the table right there in the corner.I like Boston. My husband and I met there."Have you been to the new mall?" "We're going there next week."there2 (strong form)pronoun1.(used as the subject of be, seem, appear, etc. to say that something exists): There's a man at the door.There wasn't much to eat.There's somebody singing outside.2.(used for calling attention to something): Oh look, there's Kate!

<H>they</H><audio>they.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS>(the subject of a verb) <D>the people, animals, or things that have been mentioned or are being observed now:</D> <X>We have two children. They're both boys.</X><dot><X>"Have you seen my keys?" "Yes, they're on the table."</X>

<H>thin</H><audio>thin.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>thinner</DR>; <DR>thinnest</DR>) <NR>1.</NR><D>having very little flesh on the body; not fat:</D> <X>You need to eat more. You're too thin!</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used about something solid) having a small distance between the opposite sides; not thick:</D> <X>a thin brown book</X><dot><X>a thin cotton shirt</X><dot><X>a thin slice of meat</X>

thingnoun1.countablean object that is not named: What's that red thing on the table?A pen is a thing you write with.
I need to get a few things at the grocery store.2.countable
a quality or state: The best thing about my job is the way it changes all the time.3.countablean action, event, or statement: When I get home, the first thing I do is turn on the TV.A strange thing happened to me yesterday.4.countablea fact, subject, etc.:
He told me a few things that I didn't know before.

thinkverb(past, past participle thought) 1.think (about something) to use your mind to consider something or to form connected ideas: Think before you speak.What are you thinking about?2.to consider or believe; to have as an opinion: "Do you think it's going to snow?" "No, I don't think so."What did you think of the movie?I don't think they are very good musicians.

thisdeterminer; pronoun(plural these) 1.(used for talking about somebody/something that is close to you in time or space): Take a look at this picture.These boots are really comfortable. My old ones weren't.2.(used for talking about something that was mentioned or talked about before): Where did you hear about this?3.(used for introducing somebody or showing somebody something): Chuck, this is my wife, Claudia, and these are our kids, David and Vicky.Hello, this is Maria Diaz. (= on the telephone) 4.(used with days of the week or periods of time) of today or the present week, year, etc.: Are you busy this afternoon?this Friday (= the Friday of this week)
<H>thousand</H><audio>thousand.mp3</audio><PS>number</PS><D>1,000; one more than nine hundred ninety-nine</D> <X>She earns twenty-five thousand dollars a year.</X>
<H>three</H><audio>three.mp3</audio><PS>number</PS><D>3; one more than two</D>
thrift shop (also thrift store) nouncountablea store that sells clothes and other goods given by people to raise money for a charity

<H>Thursday</H><audio>Thursday.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the day of the week after Wednesday and before Friday:</D> <X>I'm going to see her (on) Thursday.</X><dot><X>We usually play tennis on Thursdays.</X><dot><X>They don't open on Thursday.</X><dot><X>Thursday morning/afternoon/evening/night</X><dot><X>last/next Thursday</X><dot><X>The museum is open Saturday through Thursday, 10 to 4:30.</X>

<H>ticket</H><audio>ticket.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a piece of paper or card that shows you have paid to travel on public transportation, or to enter a place of entertainment, etc:</D> <X>a train ticket</X><dot><X>two tickets for the concert</X>
<H>tie</H><audio>tie.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a long thin piece of cloth that you wear around your neck with a shirt</D>

<H>time</H><audio>time.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a particular point in the day or night:</D> <X>What time is it?</X><dot><X>It's time to go home.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the passing of minutes, hours, days, etc.:</D> <X>As time passed and there was still no news, we got more worried.</X><NR>3.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>an amount of minutes, hours, days, etc.:</D> <bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>You're wasting time. Get back to work!</X><dot><X>free time</X><dot><X>We don't have time to stop now.</X><dot><bracket>countable</bracket><X>It takes a long time to learn a language.</X><NR>4.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>an occasion when somebody does something or something happens:</D> <X>I called them three times.</X><dot><X>This is the first time I've ever done this.</X><dot><X>I'll do it better next time.</X><dot><X>The last time I saw him, he looked sick.</X>
<H>tiring</H><audio>tiring.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>making you tired:</D> <X>a long and tiring trip</X>

to1 (strong form) preposition1.in the direction of; as far as: She's going to Canada.This road goes to Denver.He went to school.2.(used before the person or thing that receives, sees, etc. something): Give that to me.We should be kind to animals.3.(used before the upper limit of a range): a game suitable for children who are 8 to 12 years oldfrom beginning to endThey sell everything from matches to washing machines there.to2 (strong form) (used with verbs to form the infinitive): I want to go home now.Don't forget to write.I didn't know what to do.He asked me to go, but I didn't want to.

<H>today</H><audio>today.mp3</audio><PS>adverb;</PS> <PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>(on) this day:</D> <X>Today is Monday.</X><dot><X>What should we do today?</X><dot><X>Where is today's paper?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(in) the present age:</D> <X>Young people have more spending money today than in the past.</X><dot><X>Today's computers are much smaller than the early models.</X>

<H>together</H><audio>together.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><D>with each other; in or into the same place as or near to somebody/something else:</D> <X>Can we have lunch together?</X><dot><X>They walked home together.</X><dot><X>I'll get all my things together tonight because I want to leave early.</X>
tomatonouncountable (plural tomatoes) a soft red fruit that is often eaten raw in salads or cooked as a vegetable: tomato juicetomato sauce

tooadverb1.(used in affirmative statements and questions)
in addition; also: Red is my favorite color but I like blue, too.
Phil thinks you're right, and I do, too.2.(used before adjectives and adverbs) more than is good, allowed, possible, etc.: These boots are too small.It's too cold to go out without a coat.

topnouncountablethe highest part of something: The apartment is at the top of the building.the top of the stairs
Start reading at the top of the page.

<H>tour</H><audio>tour.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a short visit around a city, building, etc., usually in a group with somebody who explains the things in it:</D> <X>to take a guided tour through the White House</X><dot><X>Sandy gave us a tour of their new house.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a trip that you make for pleasure during which you visit many places:</D> <X>to go on a tour of the Caribbean islands</X>
<H>tower</H><audio>tower.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a tall narrow building or part of a building:</D> <X>the Eiffel Tower</X><dot><X>an observation tower</X>
<H>town</H><audio>town.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a place with many streets and buildings. A town is smaller than a city:</D> <X>She grew up in a small town in Japan.</X>
<H>traffic</H><audio>traffic.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the cars, etc. that are on a road:</D> <X>heavy/light traffic</X>

<H>train</H><audio>train.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a number of wagons that are pulled by an engine along railroad tracks:</D> <X>a commuter/passenger/freight train</X><dot><X>to catch/take a train</X><dot><X>to get on/off a train</X><dot><X>Hurry up or we'll miss the train.</X>

<H>transfer</H><audio>transfer.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS>(<DR>transferring</DR>; <DR>transferred</DR>) <CF>transfer (somebody/something) (from ...) (to ...)</CF> <D>to move, or to make somebody/something move, from one place to another:</D> <X>He was transferred to our Tokyo branch.</X><dot><X>I want to transfer $1,000 from my savings to my checking account.</X><dot><X>I transferred to this school after my freshman year.</X>

travelverbto make a trip: John travels a lot on business.
to travel by bus/airThey traveled through New England last fall.

<H>true</H><audio>true.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>right or correct; agreeing with fact:</D> <X>Is it true that Adam is leaving?</X><dot><X>Read the statements and decide if they are true or false.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>that really happened:</D> <X>The novel was based on a true story.</X>

tryverb(present participle trying; third person singular tries; past, past participle tried) to make an effort to do something: I tried to call you, but I couldn't get through.She was trying hard not to laugh.to try your best/hardestI'm sure you can do it if you try.

<H>Tuesday</H><audio>Tuesday.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the day of the week after Monday and before Wednesday:</D> <X>I'm going to see her (on) Tuesday.</X><dot><X>We usually play tennis on Tuesdays.</X><dot><X>They don't open on Tuesday.</X><dot><X>Tuesday morning/afternoon/evening/night</X><dot><X>last/next Tuesday</X><dot><X>The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 to 4:30.</X>
tunanoun(plural tuna) 1.countablea large fish that lives in the ocean 2.uncountabletuna fish the flesh of the fish, which is often sold in cans

<H>turn</H><audio>turn.mp3</audio><PS>verb </PS><CF>turn something off</CF> <D>to move the switch, etc. on a machine, etc. to stop it from working:</D> <X>He turned the TV off. </X><CF>turn something on</CF> <D>to move the switch, etc. on of machine, etc. to start it working:</D> <X>Turn the lights on!</X>
TVnouncountable, uncountable (plural TVs or TV's) television: Turn the TV on.What's on TV tonight?
<H>twenty</H><audio>twenty.mp3</audio><PS>number</PS><D>20; one more than nineteen</D>

<H>twice</H><audio>twice.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><D>two times:</D> <X>I've been to Mexico twice: once last year and once in 1999.</X><dot><X>The movie will be shown twice daily.</X><dot><X>Take the medicine twice a day.</X>
<H>type</H><audio>type.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to write something using a computer, typewriter, etc.:</D> <X>Can you type?</X><dot><X>to type a letter</X>
